text_blocks.text: EMA Battery Pack Shock Analysis
edd231804\ b229 | Analyst: U. Kanumarlapudi (ukanumar) | Lead Analyst: O. Akyol (oakyol) | TS: A. Robertson (arobert1) | 29/05/2024

Aim: A shock analysis was carried out to understand the effect of the proposed design retention plate (JLR_5530193 Rev1.1) on structural performance of the battery pack during dynamic shock events. The type 2 retention plate in cell stack row 5 is replaced with a type 1 retention plate (1.2mm thick).

Methodology: An explicit dynamic analysis using a 26g (Z axis) half sine shock pulse over 6.0 ms was applied to the model with the test rig fixture to replicate physical test TPJLR-00-047. The results are compared with the baseline model, b227 (T9U3-10J700-A-INS-01).

Results Summary :

Conclusions:
The plastic strain values for the upper retention plates meet the acceptance criteria when the type 2 retention plate is in use. Of the retention plates, the front plate has the highest plastic strain, however the responses are unchanged compared to the baseline.
The stress in the other components is increased, due to the change in stiffness of the retention plats allowing increased movement, however the plastic strain values are still within the target.
The lower cell stack joint failure is same with the baseline. The joint is not sensitive to the changes made.
Slight increase in the TIM failure is observed in cell stack row 5 but remains within acceptable limits.
Replacing the type 2 retention plate with the type 1 is a viable solution but carries increased durability risk. 

Recommendations:
Measurements of acceleration and displacement should be taken on physical test to corroborate assumptions for loading and damping. 
TIM and PET joints are recommended to be monitored for any evidence of failure during the shock test.

Z-Pos Shock – Joint Failure | b227 | b229
MS939 to PET adhesive failure | 0.90% | 0.90%
TIM Cohesive failure | 0.14% | 0.18%

EMA Battery Pack Shock Analysis
Edd231804\ b229 | Analyst: U. Kanumarlapudi (ukanumar) | Lead Analyst: O. Akyol (oakyol) | TS: A. Robertson (arobert1) | 29/05/2024
Changes on the Upper Retention Plates

Proposed Design(b229):
Geometry modification + Type-2 plate replaced by Type-1
CAD : JLR_5530193 Rev1.1
Thickness : 1.2mm, MAT: 6111T4

Baseline (b227):
CAD : T9U3-10J700-A-INS-01, 
T9U3-10J704-A-INS-01
Thickness : 1.2mm, MAT: 6111T4

Nominal Pulse
          Limits of tolerance
A – Peak acceleration of nominal pulse
D – Duration of nominal pulse

Analysis is carried out to replicate TPJLR.00.047 testing procedure consisting of a half sine-wave pulse.
Deviations from procedure: 25g applied at rig to achieve 30g on pack.

Peak Acceleration: 25 g (X and Z axis), 20 g (Y axis) 
Pulse Duration: 6.0 ms 
Test Duration per Axis: 20 pulses in each axis direction (40 pulses in total) 
Total Test Duration: 120 pulses (3 x 40 pulses per axis)

For analysis purposes, the shock is conducted by attachment to a rig fixture via the pack fixings. 

The test requirement states: 
On completion of the test or test program the sample shall be free from cracking, permanent deformation and/or any other form of breakage/fracture. 

For analysis, this is interpreted as any part that exceeds half of the strain at break, based on the number of cycles to be run. Plastic deformation that does not exceed this value is recorded for reference.
